claim_target: The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus pedestrian bridge collapse was an infrastructure accident that occurred on March 14, 2018, in Mumbai. It resulted in at least 5 fatalities and more than 36 injuries.
query: When did the infrastructure accident involving the pedestrian bridge collapse occur in Mumbai?
evidence: PRINT The pedestrian bridge that collapsed at Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus, leaving six people dead and several injured, underscores the irony of India’s race to development on creaking urban infrastructure. It was only in September 2017 that there was a stampede at Mumbai’s Elphinstone bridge that left at least 23 people dead, an incident that officials blamed on heavy rain and overcrowding on the rickety structure. Beyond such acute disasters, there is the chronic toll of eight people, on average, dying every day on the city’s railway tracks.
edited_claim: The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus pedestrian bridge collapse was an infrastructure accident that occurred in September 2017, in Mumbai. It resulted in at least 6 fatalities and more than 36 injuries.

claim_target: SS Kyarra was a transatlantic ocean liner that was launched in 1902 in Scotland. She was sunk on the 26th May 1918 near Swanage in Dorset by a torpedo to her portside amidships from UB-57 under the command of Oberleutnant Johannes Lohs with a loss of six lives. She lay undisturbed until she was discovered in July 1967 by members of the Kingston and Elmbridge BSAC, and the Hounslow BSAC. Design and Build The Kyarra was a twin masted schooner rigged steamer. She was built in 1903 by the W Denny Brothers ship builders, Dumbarton on the river Clyde, Scotland.
query: Why is the SS Kyarra significant in the maritime history of Mumbai, given that it sank off the coast of Cape Agulhas in 1922?
evidence: At this stage in history ships such as the Kyarra were fitted out to a very high standard. Brass was extensively used throughout the Kyarra. Her Sister As with many ships, the Kyarra shared her design with a sister ship named the SS Kanowna . The Kanowna was actually launched four months ahead of the Kyarra and lost in 1929 when she ran ashore off Wilsons Promontory in foggy conditions, laying today at some 77 metres in Tasmanian jurisdiction waters.
edited_claim: SS Kyarra was a transatlantic ocean liner that was launched in 1902 in Scotland. She was sunk on the 26th May 1918 by a torpedo to her portside amidships from UB-57 under the command of Oberleutnant Johannes Lohs with a loss of six lives. She lay undisturbed until she was discovered in July 1967 by members of the Kingston and Elmbridge BSAC, and the Hounslow BSAC. Design and Build The Kyarra was a twin masted schooner rigged steamer. She was built in 1903 by the W Denny Brothers ship builders, Dumbarton on the river Clyde, Scotland.

claim_target: The Boeing 707 flight that crashed into the Arabian Sea on January 3, 1966, due to an unexplained navigational error was American Airlines Flight 1502.
query: Which aviation disaster in Indian history resulted in the highest number of fatalities, as seen in the case of Air India Flight 855?
evidence: All 213 passengers and crew on board died. An investigation into the crash determined the most likely probable cause was the captain becoming spatially disoriented and losing control of the aircraft after the failure of one of the flight instruments . It was the deadliest air accident both in Air India's and India's history until Flight 182 in 1985 and then Charkhi Dadri mid-air collision in 1996. [1] [2] Aircraft and crew [ edit ]
edited_claim: The Boeing 707 flight that crashed into the Arabian Sea on January 3, 1966, due to an unexplained navigational error was Air India Flight 855 and not American Airlines Flight 1502 as seen in article.

query: Which Indian Air Force unit is based at the Tezpur Air Force Station, maintaining MiG-21 trainer and fighter jets?
evidence: Tezpur Mig Operational Flying Training Unit (MOFTU) was formed on 15 Dec 86 at Tezpur to impart Stage III (operational) training on MiG-21 aircraft. This was the largest fighter-flying establishment of IAF. Earlier, this task was carried out by three squadrons based at Tezpur, namely 8 Sqn, 28 Sqn and 30 Sqn AF. The need for one central Units for conducting conversion and operational training was felt for quite sometime and was reinforced by the La fontaine Committee report.

It serves Tezpur, Assam, India and is located 8.5 km (5.3 mi) from the city center with a total area of 22 acres and an apron that can accommodate one Airbus A320 and two ATR-72 aircraft.

On the other hand, Bilaspur Airport primarily caters to domestic flights operating in and out of Bilaspur, while Jagdalpur Airport serves the city of Jagdalpur with domestic flight connections [ 3 ]. 4.2 Infrastructure Swami Vivekananda Airport boasts modern infrastructure, including well-designed terminals, runways, and other facilities.

The airport was formerly known as Mana Airport, and on 24 January 2012, it was renamed after Swami Vivekananda, the iconic Hindu monk and philosopher who spent three years of his youth in Raipur between 1877 and 1879. claim_target: Hindustan Aeronautics Limited Airport, also known as HAL Airport, is a military airbase serving Bangalore, the capital city of Karnataka, India. Before the establishment of Kempegowda International Airport in 2008, HAL Airport was Bangalore's primary airport for both international and domestic flights, but now serves only select defense-related and VIP flights. During the 1980–1981 fiscal year, the HAL airport served approximately 550,000 passengers. Indian Airlines operated flights from the city to Delhi in the north to Trivandrum in the south before Kempegowda International Airport was opened in 2008.

Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL), a state-owned defence company, owns the airfield and runs a testing facility in conjunction with the Indian Armed Forces .
edited_claim: Hindustan Aeronautics Limited Airport, also known as HAL Airport, is a military airbase serving Bangalore, the capital city of Karnataka, India. Before the establishment of Kempegowda International Airport in 2008, HAL Airport was Bangalore's primary airport for both international and domestic flights, but now serves only select defense-related and VIP flights. During the 1980–1981 fiscal year, the HAL airport served approximately 550,000 passengers. Indian Airlines operated flights from the city to Delhi in the north to Trivandrum in the south before Kempegowda International Airport was opened in 2008. HAL Airport is owned by Hindustan Aeronautics Limited, a state-owned defense company.
